title: Glacier Bay National Park & Preserve: Name That Tune: Glacier Bay
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     Nature     Environmental Factors     Voices of Glacier Bay: Soundscapes     Name That Tune: Glacier Bay                  Name That Tune: Glacier Bay Edition         The Glacier Bay Soundscape Project records natural sounds. NPS  Test your skill at identifying common sounds heard in Glacier Bay National Park. Listen to each of the following sound clips that are presented below in random order, making notes about which sound matches the letter associated with each sound clip. Should you get stumped, read the hints that are written below each sound clip. After you're done, scroll down to the bottom of the page to compare your answers with the answer key. Listed in no particular order, the sounds include:         Harbor Porpoise Humpback Whale Sea Otter   Varied Thrush Pigeon Guillemot Harbor Seal   Arctic Tern Black Oystercatcher Brown Bear                 Sound #1    Up, exhale, inhale, down. Up, exhale, inhale down. I move through the bay with a lot of purpose.  Duration:21 seconds     Credit/ Author: NPS                     Sound #2    Someone got my name wrong--I eat mussels.   Duration:18 seconds     Credit/ Author: NPS                     Sound #3    A great singer of the seas sharing his song.  Duration:29 seconds     Credit/ Author: NPS                     Sound #4    These elegant visitors gracefully wing their way from South to North and back every year.  Duration:15 seconds                       Sound #5    John Muir once said that this creature eats "everything but granite." However, as it munches on some barnacles, it's coming awfully close.  Duration:20 seconds     Credit/ Author: NPS                     Sound #6    This critter is formal in black and white, but accessorizes with bright red feet--easily visible racing across the water before take off.  Duration:19 seconds                       Sound #7    This plaintive cry does not make it sound like this creature has found a safe harbor.  Duration:13 seconds     Credit/ Author: NPS                     Sound #8    Eating crabs and urchins requires a lot of crunching and slurping, no matter where you're dining.  Duration:17 seconds     Credit/ Author: NPS                     Sound #9    This song rarely varies and heralds the arrival of spring.  Duration:16 seconds     Credit/ Author: NPS              Answer Key  Answers by Number Sound #1  Harbor Porpoise Sound #2  Black Oystercatcher Sound #3  Humpback Whale Sound #4  Arctic Tern Sound #5  Brown Bear Sound #6  Pigeon Guillemot Sound #7  Harbor Seal Sound #8  Sea Otter Sound #9  Varied Thrush  Answer by Animal Arctic Tern  #4 Black Oystercatcher  #2 Brown Bear  #5 Harbor Porpoise  #1 Harbor Seal  #7 Humpback Whale  #3 Pigeon Guillemot  #6 Sea Otter  #8 Varied Thrush  #9
